Award.AwardTitle: Conference: The 25th Silver Anniversary Meeting of The International Environmetrics Society (TIES) Nov.21-25,2015,United Arab Emirates(UAE) University,Al Ain,United Arab Emirates

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1550435
Gel

The 25th Silver Anniversary Meeting of The International Environmetrics Society (TIES) to be held between November 21 -- 25, 2015 at the United Arab Emirates (UAE) University, Al Ain, United Arab Emirates, aims to provide an open interdisciplinary forum for cross-fertilization of ideas and enhancing cohesion between experts from statistics, environmental engineering, computer science, ecology, hydrology, social sciences, geography, and other environmental disciplines. The objective of the proposal is to request support for US graduate students, junior researchers and under-represented minorities working in the field of quantitative environmental sciences to participate at the 25th Annual Meeting of The International Environmetrics Society (TIES).

The rampant growth of digital technologies and information storage have revolutionized the volume, velocity and variety of collected information, leading to the so-called "Big Data" paradigm. In turn, this alters the way in which environmental scientists sense and analyze the available information dramatically, and ignites an ever-increasing interest in the Big Data phenomenon virtually everywhere, from smart and sustainable cities to renewable energy to health and business analytics. However, Big Data is not only about managing massive data volumes, it is much more on developing pioneering ways to connect various knowledge domains and fuse information from non-traditional sources. Indeed, what is substantially less discussed at the workshops on Big Data is the whelm of new ground-breaking interdisciplinary links that emerge from these massive information volumes. For example, what is common between Facebook, natural disaster awareness and ecological foodwebs' Who is responsible for increasing house insurance rates: outdated building standards, city infrastructure or climate change, and what can be done in the short and long-term perspectives' In the era of massive multi-platform, multi-scale and multi-source data, there appear increasingly more such examples that fall well beyond the scope of any single discipline or field of research practice and that connect across domains with new fascinating capabilities. Such problems must be addressed simultaneously from different perspectives, ranging from modern statistical sciences to pure and applied studies of Earth systems and their exposure to physical and human influences to environmental engineering and public policy. TIES2015 conference will highlight an interdisciplinary dimension of modern environmental research and will facilitate a better understanding of implications of climate change on ecosystems, economics, policy and our society as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes:

 The 25th Silver Anniversary Meeting of The International Environmetrics Society (TIES) was a 4-day conference featured by over 80 presentations, including 2 keynote addresses, 2 plenary talks, 1 panel discussion, 2 short courses, and numerous technical presentations by participants from academia, industry and federal agencies from more than 20 countries. The keynote and plenary talks were delivered by the leading international experts in environmental modeling who discussed such cutting edge topics as risk mitigation due to climate-sensitive diseases, environmental sustainability, water quality control, and environmental model complexity in the Big Data era. This provided attendees with a rare opportunity not only to learn about the most recent advances in environmental modeling but to immerse in motivating interdisciplinary discussions.

 In addition, the meeting included 2 student sessions and the annual TIES-Wiley Best Student Presentation Award.

 With the generous support of this NSF travel grant:

1)        7 participants were provided full or partial support to attend the conference, among whom there were 3 graduate students, 1 post-doctoral researchers, 2 early career researchers, 4 women and 1 Hispanic/Latino participant. All of the researchers supported by this travel grant delivered oral presentations which provided a wide platform for the international audience of TIES delegates to learn about their current research agenda.

2)        Remarkably, two of the PhD students supported by this travel grant won the TIES-Wiley  Awards for the Best Student Presentation. The first awardee is Tania Alarcon Falconi from Tufts University, USA who delivered a talk “Tap-to-household water quality deterioration: analysis of spatial and temporal uncertainties”. The second awardee is Xin Huang from University of Texas at Dallas, USA who gave a talk “Applications of Machine Learning in Environmetrics: Detecting Dynamic Trend-Based Clusters in Precipitation”.

 

 

Broader Impact

 The TIES Annual Meetings are an interdisciplinary international forums that aim to foster the development and sound application of statistical and other quantitative methods in the environmental sciences, environmental engineering and environmental monitoring and protection. TIES promotes the participation of statisticians, mathematicians, scientists and engineers in the solution of environmental problems and emphasizes the need for collaboration and for clear communication between individuals from different disciplines and between researchers and practitioners.

  This travel grant significantly benefited US-based graduate students and early career researcher by allowing them to participate in TIES2015 and thus by fostering their awareness of interdisciplinary relationships in modern environmental studies at the interface of the Big Data paradigm as well as by enhancing their capacity for critical collaborative thinking. Moreover, more than half of the awardees were women and/or from underrepresented ethnic groups, which strongly advocates for creating a more inclusive and open atmosphere in STEM and mentoring future diverse leadership.
